items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely between approximately 12:30pm and 2pm this afternoon, Thursday 9th October.  This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tide levels and large waves may lead to flooding this morning, Thursday 09/10/2025. Flooding of roads, low lying land, and exposed areas of the coast is possible. 

Flooding is possible between 04:30AM and 07:00AM. Areas most at risk include exposed areas of the coast particularly around Whitby, and The North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and the tidal River Esk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are currently in a period of high tides so this alert may be re-issued if necessary. This message will be updated by 08:00PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 04:45 on 09/10/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 15 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain steady for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 09/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The forecast high-water is 8:00 PM today 08/10/25 with a level of 7.72 mAOD and a Force 4 North-Westerly wind. The second forecast high-water is 8:15 AM on 09/10/25 with a level of 7.45 mAOD and a Force 2 North-Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until tomorrow evening due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill.
Please be careful along low-lying land near watercourses where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding remains possible over the high tide this evening. High water at Ilfracombe on
Wednesday evening is at 19:45 BST, times of high water will vary along the coast.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to
monitor the situation and update on Wednesday
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe
on Tuesday evening is 5.12 mAOD

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
High tides are expected to reach the flood alert threshold overnight which may lead to flooding between 01:30 AM and 03:00 AM on 09/10/2025.  The impacted locations are:
 
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 02:00 AM
 
Eastford Road, peaking around 02:15 AM
 
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 02:30 AM
 
Knutsford Road, peaking around 02:30 AM
 
It is possible that river levels will also affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
 
The lunchtime tide tomorrow, 09/10/2025 will not reach flood alert, but the overnight tide on 10/10/2025 will pass the flood alert threshold.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High spring tides are expected until Friday 10 October. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

The morning tide at 01:00 AM on Thursday 9 October will reach flood alert level at Sandside, Arnside and Canal Foot. The following high tide at 13:25 PM on Thursday 9 October is forecast to reach flood alert level at Sandside. The early morning tide at 01:45 AM on Friday 10 October is forecast to reach flood alert level at Sandside and Arnside. Tide levels may be high 2 hours either side of peak level timings.

Areas that may be affected are the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Canal Foot, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as tidal floodwater is expected to impact these low lying areas. Do not attempt to drive through floodwater.
 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Thursday 9 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is possible from 12:30 AM on Thursday 9 October. Tide levels will be at their highest between midnight and 03:00 AM. 

Areas most at risk include low lying coastline at Skinburness Marsh and at Port Carlisle. 

We do not expect the following high tides on Thursday afternoon and early Friday morning to reach flood alert level.

We are closing flood gates at Skinburness Marsh.

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Thursday 9 October, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 12:45 AM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from tomorrow's midday tide. However further flooding is possible tomorrow night due to higher than normal tides, with the high tides peaking at 01:30am on 10/10/2025
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 9:30 AM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 12:45 AM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After the high tide overnight, the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected. We do not expect to see similar impacts from tomorrows midday high tide.
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.
We will remove this message by 9:00 AM on 09/10/2025.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 12:45 AM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow afternoon.
We have closed flood gates at St. Georges Quay, Lancaster.
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.
We will remove this message by 9:00 AM on 09/10/2025.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning between 07:15am and 09:15am on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.66mAODN at 08:15am on Thursday 9th October which is 0.07m above tide tables, wind force 5, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  tomorrow morning between 07:15am and 09:15am on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.66mAODN at 08:15am on Thursday 9th October which is 0.07m above tide tables, wind force 5, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 9th October.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are currently in a period of high tides so this alert may be re-issued if necessary.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides from Thursday morning may lead to flooding.
 
Flooding is possible around the Thursday morning  (09/10/2025) 5 AM high tide, between 4 AM and 6 AM.

Flooding is also possible on subsequent hight tides including the 5:45 AM on Friday 10/10/2025.
 
Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast, specifically at Newcastle Quayside.
 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve following the Friday afternoon tide when no further flooding is expected.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid roads, footpaths and carparks at Newcastle Quayside, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  in the early hours tomorrow between 00:45am and 02:45am on Thursday 9th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Clacton of 2.84mAODN at 1:45am on Thursday 9th October which is 0.07m above tide tables, wind force 3, North Westerly.    Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 9th October.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 07:15am and 09:15am Thursday 09 October 2025.  Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.80 mAODN at 08:15am, on Thursday 09 October 2025, which is 0.04m above tide tables, wind Force 4, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Thursday 09 October 2025 at 8:45pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00am Thursday 09 October 2025.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 07:15am and 09:15am Thursday 09 October 2025.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.80mAODN at 08:15am, on Thursday 09 October 2025, which is 0.04m above tide tables, wind Force 4, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Thursday 09 October 2025 at 8:45pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00am Thursday 09 October 2025.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: A flood alert has been issued due to a period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest around 20:15 this evening 07/10/25 and between 08:30 and 08:45 on Wednesday 08/10/25. Flooding to roads and low-lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the time of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides. Predicted peaks at Newport 7.1m to 7.3m and Avonmouth 7.5m to 7.7m around 20:15 this evening Tuesday 07/10/25. Wednesday morning tide peaks Newport 6.9m to 7.2m and Avonmouth 7.4m to 7.6m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 08/10/25, or as the situation changes.

No other high tides are expected to reach the Flood Warning threshold in this current sequence.

Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.description: Tidal Trent for riverside areas from Gainsborough to the Humber confluence

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby River gauge as a result of high spring tides.  Flooding is possible on high tides from 07:30 on 09/10/2025 to 08:30 on 09/10/2025. Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed as we are no longer forecasting significant impacts for the tide on Thursday morning. The associated alert remains in place as minor localised impacts are possible relating to the high spring tides. Continue to take care, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue the warning if required for any tides.

items.description: North Sea coast at Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tide levels and large waves are expected to lead to flooding this morning, Thursday 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible between 06:00AM and 08:30AM. Areas most at risk include properties on the east side of Kilnsea, and Easington, including the Caravan Parks. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 04:00PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High spring tides may lead to flooding this evening. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, however property flooding is not expected.

The highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 8:30 PM on 08/10/2025. Flooding is possible an hour and a half either side of this time.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.61 mAODN at 8:30 PM on 08/10/2025, with Northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Further flood alerts may be issued for this current sequence of high Spring tides.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Highest tide level is expected to be on the Isle of Sheppey and North Kent Coast at 1:45 PM on 09/10/2025. Flooding is possible 1 hour either side of this time.

Areas most at risk include low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths.

Coastal conditions are expected to improve tomorrow afternoon and no flooding is expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Sheerness of 3.46 mAODN at 1:45 PM on 09/10/2025with westerly force 3 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

We will remove this message by 2:45 PM on 09/10/2025.
